Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Culturally Relevant Enterprise Development (CRED) for Tribal Colleges Listen and Learn
Award.AbstractNarration:
We propose a "listen and learn" workshop to facilitate partnerships between NSF and Native American/Alaska Native (NA/AN) communities in the US to develop an innovation and STEM/STEAM-based entrepreneurship curriculum and incubator program. The goals are to collect, understand, and document best practices among existing entrepreneurship incubator programs in NA/AN communities as well as envision what an entrepreneurship incubator program could look like. Workshop participants will come away with knowledge of community needs, existing, existing successful models for NA/AN entrepreneurship programs, NSF entrepreneurship, lean launchpad, and the business model canvas; skills including: Customer discovery process; STEM, social, and community-based culturally-relevant entrepreneurship; positive attitudes around defining individual entrepreneurial mindsets and imagining a future NA/AN entrepreneurship incubator program. The activity will help advance understanding of best practices among existing entrepreneurship incubator programs in NA/AN communities and to help develop a vision for what an NSF-sponsored program for NA/AN STEM entrepreneurs could look like. It will lay a ground work for a pilot cohort of NA/AN entrepreneurs to participate in a culturally relevant I-Corps variant, Culturally Relevant Enterprise Development (CRED) program that could ultimately be expanded to other communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this “listen and learn” workshop was to facilitate partnerships between NSF and Native American and Alaska Native (NA/AN) communities to develop an innovation and STEM/STEAM-based entrepreneurship curriculum and incubator program. The goals of this workshop are:

  1. Collect, understand, and document best practices among existing entrepreneurship incubator programs in NA/AN communities.
  2. Discuss what an NA/AN entrepreneurship incubator program could look like.
  3. Create a robust ecosystem of NA/AN entrepreneurship supporters (including entrepreneurs, business and government leaders, economic development centers, academic faculty and staff, and students).

 

The workshop brought together 38 participants from across the NA/AN entrepreneurship ecosystem, including entrepreneurs, business and government leaders, economic development centers, academic faculty and staff, and students. Sessions included a panel discussion of community needs and solution insights, case studies and discussion of exemplar NA/AN innovation programs and teams, customer discovery interviews (based on the i-Corps model), and a brainstorming session on imagining future communities supported by an indigenous entrepreneurship incubator program.

 

Participants came away with knowledge of community needs, existing successful models for NA/AN entrepreneurship programs, NSF entrepreneurship programs, the lean launchpad, and the business model canvas. They also came away with skills including the customer discovery process and STEM, social, and community-based culturally-relevant entrepreneurship. Through networking connections made at the conference, participants came away with positive attitudes around defining individual entrepreneurial mindsets and imagining a future NA/AN entrepreneurship incubator program.

Modified by: Shawn S Jordan

Discuss what an NA/AN entrepreneurship incubator program could look like. Create a robust ecosystem of NA/AN entrepreneurship supporters (including entrepreneurs, business and government leaders, economic development centers, academic faculty and staff, and students). The workshop brought together 38 participants from across the NA/AN entrepreneurship ecosystem, including entrepreneurs, business and government leaders, economic development centers, academic faculty and staff, and students. Participants came away with knowledge of community needs, existing successful models for NA/AN entrepreneurship programs, NSF entrepreneurship programs, the lean launchpad, and the business model canvas. Through networking connections made at the conference, participants came away with positive attitudes around defining individual entrepreneurial mindsets and imagining a future NA/AN entrepreneurship incubator program.
